Other people believe it is an individual right (so each individual has the right to keep and bear arms).
 
 The other big argument of late has been the "assault weapon" ban. In 1994 a bill was signed into law liniting the sale of "assault weapons", which were weapons that contained certain features such as bayonet lugs, flash supressors, pistol grips, and certain other features.
 
 The anti-gunners argue that assault weapons are dangerous killing machines. The pro gunners argue that the ban is just foolish, as it does nothing to address functional issues of the weapons and bans purely cosmetic features. I would have to go with the pro-gunners on this one. I don't recall ever in my entire life hearing of a crime commited with a bayonet. 
 
 There is an argument over wether certain safety measures, such as gun locks should be mandatory. On this one, the anti-gunners claim they will save lives, the pro gunners claim that we have had guns in this country since the very beginning, and requiring trigger locks is a hindeerance to gun owners and an unneccesary expense to gun manufaturers. Pro gunners argue that by teaching people the safe use and storage of firearms they don't need gun locks.
 
 The big problem is that both sides have attracted a "lunatic finge". When doing your report, you need to be careful about any statistics you find from either the pro gunners or the anti gunners. Unfortunatly, those on the lunatic fringe prefer to spin numbers, and sometimes outright lie about them than to give the public honest, reliable information.
